skill.name: using-superpowers
skill.description: Use when starting any conversation - establishes how to find and use skills, requiring Skill tool invocation before ANY response including clarifying questions

skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only workflow guidelines. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, no environment variable access. The skill provides instructions for skill invocation and is safe for publication.

content.value_statement: AI assistants often skip skill checks, leading to inconsistent workflows. This skill establishes mandatory skill invocation rules, ensuring the right tools are used for every task. It creates disciplined, predictable behavior across all conversations.
actual_capabilities: Check for applicable skills before every response
Invoke Skill tool for any task with even 1% skill relevance
Prioritize process skills over implementation skills
limitations: Does not provide domain-specific implementation guidance
Requires other skills to exist for invocation
Cannot execute tasks directly without other skills

use_cases.title: Enforce skill-based workflows
use_cases.description: Ensure AI assistants follow consistent skill invocation patterns across all conversations and projects

use_cases.title: Standardize AI behavior
use_cases.description: Create predictable AI responses by establishing mandatory skill checks before any task execution

use_cases.title: Prevent skipping workflows
use_cases.description: Stop AI from rationalizing around discipline by requiring skill tool invocation before responses

prompt_templates.title: Skill Check Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Check for applicable skills for this task. If any skill might help, invoke it using the Skill tool before responding.

prompt_templates.title: Confirm Skill Usage
prompt_templates.prompt: Before asking clarifying questions, check if a skill applies. If yes, invoke it first and let the skill guide the clarification process.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-skill Priority
prompt_templates.prompt: Identify all applicable skills. Apply process skills like brainstorming or debugging first, then implementation skills. Use the priority order from using-superpowers.

prompt_templates.title: Enforce Discipline
prompt_templates.prompt: Stop. Use the using-superpowers skill to verify you are not rationalizing. Check if any skill applies before proceeding with this task.

output_examples.input: Fix the login bug in the React app
output: Using debugging skill to analyze the bug systematically
Creating todo items per debugging checklist
Will use frontend-debugging or react-specific skills if identified during debugging

best_practices: Check for skills before EVERY response, including clarifying questions
When in doubt about skill applicability, err on the side of checking
Read the current version of each skill - they evolve over time
anti_patterns: Rationalizing that you know the approach without checking skills
Exploring or gathering info before checking what skills tell you to do

faq.question: What if no skills apply to my task?
faq.answer: Proceed normally, but document why no skills applied for future reference and skill requests.

faq.question: How do I know if a skill might apply?
faq.answer: If there is even a 1% chance a skill could help, invoke it. Better to check than skip.

faq.question: What about urgent or quick tasks?
faq.answer: Quick tasks still need skill checks. The skill itself will guide if a full workflow is unnecessary.

faq.question: Can I combine multiple skills?
faq.answer: Yes. When multiple skills apply, prioritize process skills (brainstorming, debugging) over implementation skills.

faq.question: Does this skill replace my judgment?
faq.answer: No. It enforces discipline around checking skills. Your judgment applies skill principles to context.

faq.question: How do I add new skills to my workflow?
faq.answer: Install additional skills via the CLI. This skill will then check for and invoke them when relevant.
